instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S5_AVREF_SMC: What is PP3V3_S5_AVREF_SMC? PP3V3_S5_AVREF_SMC Is a reference voltage for the SMC’s voltage sensors & other sensors..
definitions.U5110: What is U5110? This chip is responsible for SMC_RESET_L in many Macbook models..
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.R7121: What is R7121? Current sense resistor between charger current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H around 4v, quarter fan spin, or battery not charging..
definitions.R7105: What is R7105? resistor between charger and CHGR_DCIN pin of ISL6259, if CHGR_DCIN is low then this resistor is probably blown. When PPBUS_G3H is low or missing this is something to check if your model has CHGR_DCIN along R7005. .
definitions.R7122: What is R7122? Current sense resistor between charger current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H around 4v, quarter fan spin, or battery not charging..
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan going nuts
threads.message:
hey all i got a macbook air and although works fine fan spins up - just after boot.
Fan connector looks good - no damage.
I have tried another fan.
I have tried another io board.
<RESISTOR>R6060</RESISTOR> <RESISTOR>R6061</RESISTOR> <RESISTOR>R6065</RESISTOR> <RESISTOR>R6010</RESISTOR> all measuring good
<TRANSISTOR>Q6060</TRANSISTOR> been replaced twice.
what am i missing?
thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan going nuts
threads.message: Does it slowly increase and stay on or does it just spin crazy automatically?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan going nuts
threads.message: slowly increase then stays high.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan going nuts
threads.message: So you have a sensor issue. Runs ASD 156 on this and see which sensor is failing.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan going nuts
threads.message: no errors in asd? crazy?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan going nuts
threads.message:
Did you try other trackpad and cable?
Also run some software for temperature indications.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan going nuts
threads.message: Hmm weird. Try without the webcam plugged in. If no change, try new trackpad and cable like 2informaticos said as well as a new battery. If still same issue, then has to be corrosion near SMC would be my guess

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan going nuts
threads.message: I forgot the webcam cable; ALS sensor is on the same...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan going nuts
threads.message: ok another issue i noticed, when battery is disconnected and reconnected. when i plug in charger fan will spin then turn off it will repeat this and on the 3rd time it will turn on and chime? is this normal?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan going nuts
threads.message: and also what is the best way to reflow smc? 350c? 7/10 airflow? should i remove silicon?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan going nuts
threads.message: Yes 3437 goes on off on off on. Best thing to do is remove the edge bonding then use around 250 celsius doesn't have to be super airflow to remove any junk from under it. If the same, then reflow at 430 celsius full air flow.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan going nuts
threads.message:
3437 MLB starts in that way, so is correct; valid for 3435 too.
Nobody can know the correct settings for your hot air station.
When talk about reflow, we give board temp as refference.
Reflow to burn crap under chip is doing at 180 degrees, no more.
You must know how to set your station, as its indication will be 400 degress maybe (or more), depending of distance and air flow too.
If you want to melt th balls, you will need to reach 230 degrees onboard; a small bottom heater can help a lot (I use MLINK 853A).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan going nuts
threads.message:
thanks for all your valuable input. i can easily get things off the board at 350c, i use hakko fr-810b. I am just suprised there could be crap under smc as this has no previous history of water? but who knows?

i checked out the mlink 853a, that is very cheap! I have been looking at using preheater I really want something thinner but price goes $$$$$

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan going nuts
threads.message: reflowed smc still spinning hard :(

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan going nuts
threads.message: Hmmm this is a weird one. Try with just a known good trackpad and I/O board and cable plugged in. Let it boot all the way up with an SSD. If it’s still doing it, there surely must be a sensor that is reading wrong. Try booting into the OS and running HWMonitor on it to see if any sensors are reporting high

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan going nuts
threads.message:
I ran techtools PRO but no sensor errors, i really want to get to the bottom of this so i will get hwmonitor and run that too.

thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan going nuts
threads.message:
ok ran asd and got many errors.

SMC 0x0 -- smc critical sensor
Temperature (THSP) -- Thunderbolt Proximity (test #1)
Temperature (TM0P) -- MLB top side
Temperature (TW0P) -- Airport proximity
Temperature (Tm0P) -- Memory proximity

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan going nuts
threads.message: Check <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_AVREF_SMC</SIGNAL> presence first.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan going nuts
threads.message: its not there. this is s5 line? so even with charger it should be readable?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan going nuts
threads.message:
Check <CHIP>U5110</CHIP> voltages.
AVREF is required for A/D converters from SMC.
If no present, all sensors cannot be properly read...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan going nuts
threads.message: now voltages are present on <CHIP>U5110</CHIP> but no fan spin no boot. i was probing around on <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>. i might of accidentally bridged pin 12-11? could this be the cause?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan going nuts
threads.message: i got 3.4v on ppbus now? I also notice <RESISTOR>R7122</RESISTOR>/<RESISTOR>R7121</RESISTOR> is both dead and there is big hole in <RESISTOR>R7105</RESISTOR> i replace and it burnt again!?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan going nuts
threads.message:
Why didn't think you why <RESISTOR>R7105</RESISTOR> got burnt???
I bet <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> is fried.
Check <CAPACITOR>C7105</CAPACITOR>, just in case.
Also check <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR> before power up the board again.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan going nuts
threads.message:
i change <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> again same issue resistors burnt
how to check <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR>? just see if short?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan going nuts
threads.message:
ok got booting again everything is good. replaced isl and resistors that were blown. good news is the <CHIP>U5110</CHIP> has <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> coming in now and also its shooting out 3.3v from pin 8
i will wash and retest board in machine? is it normal that out side machine board only with charger only and NOTHING connected - the fans run 100%?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan going nuts
threads.message: still spinning up. after boot

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan going nuts
threads.message:
Fan will go high if trackpad is not connected.
Palm rest temperature sensor is not detected.
Run ASD again, if needed...
